name.value: Charmed: le jeu de cartes à jouer et à collectionner

item.description:
Charmed CCG is on based on the television series Charmed. 
One player is good side as Leo, Chris and all the other heroes of the series. Second player is bad side playing the demons.

In this game You must complete missions. To do this, you use your characters. Bonus cards allow you to strengthen the power of your characters. You have also Event cards that allow you to counter the moves of your opponent!

Unusual game in that it was made by the Royal Navy Careers Service, as a tool to attract youngsters to a career choice.

From the rules card:
How to become an expert at recognising the shlps. missiles and aircraft of the Royal Navy.
 You can use these cards in many ways that will help you memorise the 'hardware’ of today’s Royal Navy.

A Recognition Quiz is one game you can play. Each card is numbered so you earn that number of points for every ship you Identify,

Here are two card games you can play:
Navy Snap—Deal seven or more cards to each player. Place remainder of pack in centre of table. Play in rotation, each player trying to match from his own hand the top card of the table pack (which is discarded on to a second pile).
Players match cards by producing any ship of the same type — i.e. any class of frigate with any other class of frigate; a nuclear sub with a nuclear sub but any non-nuclear class of sub with any other non-nuclear.
Players may be challenged on their matching and. If they have mixed one type with another, they have to take their card back and forfeit their throw next time round.
First player out wins.

Navy Rummy — Deal seven cards to each player. Play like ordinary rummy, collecting sets of three (i.e. three subs of any type. three aircraft. three ships of any type) and runs of four (in ascending or descending order of displacement tonnage — i.e. carriers, auxiliaries, cruisers. Polaris subs, missile destroyers, frigates and so on).
First player out wins.

Win a presentation colour picture for your own idea. If you think up a game of your own — which must be simple as well as fun — let's know about it at the address on the other side of this card. If we like It we’ll send a presentation colour picture of a modern Royal Navy ship or aircraft.

Game is played by pulling chips from a bag. Each player has a Search bag and a Dogfight bag. Players start by using their Search bag to find opponents aircraft. Player to find the other players aircraft gets to draw from their Dogfight bag and will either lose sight of the enemy or shoot one of opponents planes down.
Very easy.
Comes with 44 chips and 4 bags. 12 of the chips are tokens to keep track of your aircraft. These tokens are being produced now and will be shipped free of charge if you order before they are complete. These are not required for game play but does add a little to the game.

British quiz game, linked to the TV Times, Britains listing magazine for non-BBC TV channels.

The cards have images on them relating someone or a series that should be familiar to you. You get 20 seconds to study the card before being challenged by questions about the image. Correct answers help you move round the board which goes through four different TV channels. If you are first to the Off Switch, you win.

The game consists of 66 cards (54 numbered cards 1-54 and 12 betting cards, 2 for each players "more" or "less")
Number cards are shuffled and 6 cards are dealt for each player.

The object of the game is to get rid of his number cards first.

In his turn player plays a card on the table face-down. The other players bet on this card with their betting cards what they think is it greater or lower card as the last card.
Player who loses the bet, picks an additional card.
Some wildcards allow You to not pick up a card if You lose a bet.

name.value: Scripts and Scribes: The Dice Game

item.description:
As a medieval monk, you are charged with increasing the prestige of the abbey's collection of historical and sacred texts. By acquiring the resources for manuscript illustration and reproduction, your abbey produces and sells its valuable works, thereby bringing in finances necessary for maintaining a fine abbey. Will you succeed in making your abbey the most prestigious of all?

The goal of Scripts and Scribes: The Dice Game is to acquire gold and to collect resources – scrolls, manuscripts, pigments, quills, ink – to exchange for gold. The game is a dice version of Scripts and Scribes (aka, Biblios) and follows the same basic theme, but with interesting changes due to the use of dice. As in Scripts and Scribes, players compete in five different categories and the values of the categories change during the game. In addition, depending upon the dice roll, there may be many or few auctions during the game in which players auction their resources for gold or auction gold for resources.

link.value: Scripts and Scribes: The Dice Game – Mini Expansion

item.description:
On June 26, 1876, Lt. Col. George A. Custer drove his seven companies of the U.S. 7th Cavalry into the valley of the Little Bighorn River in search of that last big victory to cement his place in history. There he met a vast gathering of Native American nations not willing to back down from the normal tactics of the U.S. Army. Custer planted his name in history, but for the wrong reasons as he and 255 of his men were slaughtered at the Little Bighorn.

Little Bighorn Rummy brings back both the famous and infamous cast list of this incident to create an unusual style of rummy, specifically a set collection game in which players collect both Native American and U.S. Cavalry melds to secure points while attempting to empty their hand. Special cards and support cards alter play, allowing players to play single cards (chiefs) to their table, look through the discard pile, and help Lt. Col. Custer (worth -20 points) escape the scene, among other actions. The first player to achieve 150 points wins.

item.description: Ladder Logic is a puzzle and voting game where players compete to turn on the switches that will activate their gear network in an effort to get the clock tower working once again. Players manage workers on a shared main board that influence their actions on their player boards where they maintain a network of gears.

name.value: Mayan Sun, Aztec Destiny: 500 BC – AD 2012 – Beyond∞

item.description:
In Mayan Sun, Aztec Destiny: 500 BC - AD 2012 - Beyond∞, players are ancient astronomers reading the stars and sun patterns. Using the Mayan Haab agricultural calendar invented in roughly 500 BC, players inform their villages when to best plant their seeds so that they may grow a tremendous harvest to feed their people. After their seeds are planted, the astronomers recommend rituals to aid in their harvest and their reading of prophecies in the stars, but problems arise. A village conducting a ritual to help their crop could be stealing the power of the sun or cosmos from a nearby neighbor. Droughts may crush other villages.

After crops have been harvested, the ancient astronomers now begin to forecast the prophecies of the stars. Using the technologies found in the Aztec Calendar, the important messages from the sky above may be telling us when and how the world will end. Players wager a bet about the ultimate destiny. With their knowledge of Prophecy they may influence this ultimate end, and also may know the exact date! Could the world end by the fires of a super volcano in 1969 AD, or will an alien race arrive in 2012 AD, or will a super nova occur light years away destroying our planet in 3,000,000,000 years? Players are now trusted prophets and will have the knowledge of the end of time.

The game can be played as either a basic SUN game or an advanced DESTINY game. The basic Sun game involves players moving the tiles by conducting rituals, tile positioning can help or hinder players as they grow crops and collect prophetic knowledge. Players in the basic game will score for the amount of villages they feed and Prophecy tokens they collect. The Destiny game is for players desiring a more involved game in which Prophecy tokens, earned conducting ritual, must be used to either influence the value of villages, investments in the future, and/or influencing how and when the world may come to an end.

item.description:
A Texan-made American football game based on the exciting new tactic at the time, the T-Formation. This is not a statistical game and is played head-to-head against your opponent. After choosing a card for the type of play you would like your team to accomplish and then refered to a table that gives the result of the play.

I think it could be played solitaire because I cannot see any interaction that would happen each turn.

British card game, described as a game and a puzzle.

Any number of players from two upwards can play. The cards are dealt round in the usual manner, faces (pictures) downwards. The players must not look at the face side of their cards. The player left of dealer leads and turns his or her top card face up in the centre of the table. Each player plays a card in turn Each successive card should be quickly played so that a "body" is fitted to the "Head" on the last card played. The title line "Grandfather's Whiskers" on the back of each card indicates the half containing a "body."

Lots of combinations of head and body will be created to the amusement of all the players, but when Grandfather's Head appears on Grandfather's Feet, players must call "Out" or "In". This is because his feet might be under the eiderdown on the card or poking out from under the eiderdown. The first player to call correctly takes all the cards in the centre. If a wrong call is made, that playerr must give every other player a card from his hand.

The objective is to be the last player with all the cards.

THE SIX JIG-TYPE PUZZLES
The backs of the cards comprise six different jig-type puzzles. The cards numbered from 1 to 8 constitute a quite simple puzzle, for the picture is formed merely by placing the cards in a certain order with their edges touching. In the second puzzle group (numbers 9 to 16) the cards overlap.
The remaining groups, numbers 17-24, 25-32, 33-40 and 41-48, become successively more difficult last group (41-48) in which Grandfather and his Whiskers are depicted, is the most advanced puzzle of the whole series.

name.value: Le Livre de la jungle: Histoire à jouer
Bernard et Bianca: Histoire à jouer

item.description:
Similar to Chutes and Ladders.

Players roll the dice, place as many tiles on the board starting with the first tile numbered 1 and move his game piece accordingly telling the jungle story showed on the tiles.

Player who place the last tile and reach to end of the story first is the winner.

The hardest part of design isn’t doing the design. It’s working with everyone else without wanting to run screaming for the hills.

Collaborating with smart people on challenging problems is, inevitably, fraught with conflict. Conflict can be good for creative work, moving a project forward as designers wrestle with the challenge. But not all conflict is healthy, and frankly most designers aren’t, shall we say, diplomats.

Surviving Design Projects is, among other things, a little game to help designers hone their people skills. It’s pretty easy. Each player takes turns being the Creative Director. He or she turns over a Situation card, and then tells a little story about the situation shown. She can make it up or draw from her own experience.

Let's say I turn over the situation "Lack of Inputs." Maybe I make up this story:

Though the client has provided stacks of user research, they can’t offer us any clear business priorities. They’re just asking us to make their site better without giving us a sense of what they want to accomplish. I need to go talk to the client about this, and try to get them to give us some inputs.

Each player around the table chooses a Pattern card from their hand and places it face-up next to the situation card. The Creative Director chooses one player to go first and describe how they would apply the pattern to the situation. That is, to describe the technique would they use to make the conflict productive. Let’s say one player uses “Make Educated Guesses” and describes it this way:

The Make Educated Guesses pattern suggests we fill in the holes ourselves with some assumptions. I guess the idea is that we’re smart people, so we should know what the starting point is. We could brainstorm a list of assumptions about the project’s business priorities, then share that with the client to validate it.

The Creative Director then chooses which technique she would use to deal with the situation and leads a group discussion about the choice. The person who suggested the pattern receives the situation card. The player to the Creative Director’s left becomes the next creative director, flipping the top Situation card, and starting again. At the end of the game, the person who has the most Situation cards is the winner.

So that’s it. It’s a pretty simple game, but the idea is to get people talking about difficult situations in a no-strings environment.

name.value: Le Livre de la Jungle: à la recherche de Mowgli

item.description:
Character from the children novel Mowgli.

Mowgli, Shanti and Ranjan is threatened by Shere Khan (the man-eating tiger) and hide themselves in the ruins deep in the jungle.

Players are Bagheera, Baloo and baby elephant and they search for them rolling the dice and following the footprints of Mowgli. Who first discovered the hiding place wins the game.

Popkult is a swedish pop cultural trivia game where you answer questions in several categories to be the first to reach Hollywood.

During your turn you pick question cards from your hand and may assign questions to any other player. There are also event cards that can be used to move forward, force pick up of new cards, or interrupt your opponents and answer for them.

The game ends when all cards are played or one player reaches the last space on the board.

item.description:
At start each player in turn places 7 game pieces of his color on the game board. Then, the game continues by sliding each turn a gamepiece in a free adjacent position. 
The first who close a square with four of his game pieces wins.

In Six-Word Memoirs, teams use SMITH Magazine's famous storytelling form to guess the names of famous people, places, and pop culture icons. Teams use imagination and quick word-writing wit to create and identify six-word descriptions on more than 1000 different topics.

Can you describe George Washington, Lindsay Lohan or the City of San Francisco in exactly six words? You will need to if you want to win Six-Word Memoirs by University Games. The game invites teams of players to battle for excellence in defining and deciphering famous topics of people and places in exactly six words. For example, do you know who, “Julie’s mom, wife of Tricky Dicky” would be? If you guessed Pat Nixon, then you’ve got it.

Six-Word Memoirs is the creation of Larry Smith’s online storytelling community, SMITH Magazine. Smith first introduced the concept of describing a person in just six words on his web community and in one of the first Twitter feeds in 2006. He called the form the “Six-Word Memoir” and this simple way to define a life went on to become New York Times bestselling book, Not Quite What I Was Planning in 2008. Now the wildly popular concept jumps to life in a competitive team-based game.

item.description:
After dealing out all cards to each player equally, Players will play one card each round, starting with the first player, and rotating to the right. Cards are played by alternating face-up and face-down: the first card each round is played face down, the next card is played face up, and the third card is played face down, and so on, until each player has played one card. Starting again with the first player, everyone will take one card of their choice, choosing either a face-up card, or pressing their luck by choosing a face-down card.

The cards represent different fruits, with varying number values. Players are trying to get the highest values into their stack. There are also three special cards:
 Super-fruit: this card will double the value of a single fruit card,
 Caterpillar: the hungry caterpillar will reduce the value of one or more cards by half,
 Pistachio: the delicious nut will lure a caterpillar away, canceling out one caterpillar card.

After all cards are exhausted, scoring begins. Highest score wins.

name.value: Arm Chair Quarterback: A Game of Skill

item.description:
This game was manufactured by Novelty Manufacturing Co. out of Richmond, CA in 1955. Arm chair quarterback is a game that consists of a game board, first down/yardage marker, 11 red defensive pawns, 1 tan offensive pawn, and a huddleboard with two metal stands.

The object of the gameplay: The huddleboard is placed in the middle of the board allowing the offensive and defensive teams to call their play. The offense has 9 spots/plays to place their pawn. The defense has 11 pawns with 16 spots to try and stop the play of the offense. When the huddleboard is removed each team can see the result of the play. At each spot on the board a result of the play is posted as whether its a gain, loss, turnover, TD, or incomplete. After each play, you record the information on the yardage/down marker. Like football, the offensive player must make 10 yards in 4 downs to continue or the the board is turned around to switch positions. The game can be played for 30 or 60 minutes depending on your preference. Note: All plays are based on national averages. There is no advantage to either team. It all depends on how good you are at playing QUARTERBACK!

A Charades game that has a stack of religious quotes to act out. Play as individuals or teams. A player reference card advises about the usual Charades-type signals for book, play, etc. but it also gives a lot of signals especially thought up by the designers to be useful in a biblical connection.

"Fall of the Titans" is a 2-player asymmetrical card game, based on the video game "Shadow of the Colossus." In "Fall," one player takes on the role of Ronin, a human assigned with the task of defeating the great Titan...which is played by the other player.

Each player has a different process and actions that they perform. Essentially, the Titan player sets up a defense, the Ronin player determines a course of action against those defenses, results are determined, and the player then moves. But careful consideration must be taken into account with regards to planning, bluffing, and resources available in hand.

The game uses a standard deck of cards, a pawn, and some coins or some other markers, in addition to the Titan board.

Bible quiz game. A card is read out and players or teams try to identify the subject. All things will be something associated with the Bible. There are 4 clues to a card, each getting easier. So, if no-one is correct after one clue, then the second clue to the same answer is tried. Then a third and a fourth, if needed. With only 50 or so cards and only one question per card, I guess replayability is not so hot.

If a player gets it right, he is given the cards and the player or team with the most cards at the end, wins.

Edwardian game that rewards good jiggling and joggling!

The rules (as written inside the box lid):

THE FROG RACE
“JIGGLE JOGGLE”
BY ROYAL LETTERS PATENT
— —
DIRECTIONS
Any number of players may engage in this game, the more the better.
Place all frogs in a row, the object being to jerk the frogs along the whole length of the cords, the first frog that passes the winning line is the victor.
TO START
Tie one end of the cord to a chair or table, the cord being about nine inches from the ground.
The players then go to the other end of the cords, then by pulling and slackening the cords alternately, the frogs will leap forward.
The frogs must start from where the cords are held. When they pass the winning line, indicated on the floor, the frogs may by reversed and raced back to tbe start if players desire.
BRITISH MANUFACTURE. Made in England

The Frogs are made of card and the cord is around 8 feet long.

On the box it is enthusiastically recommended by two magazines at the time. And there is also a cute verse about the fun that will be had with the game.

Welcome to the world of Uncharted: The Board Game! In this game, you take on the role of a treasure hunter and compete with other players to gain the most Victory Points. The variety of cards that you collect represent skills and items necessary for or sought after by treasure hunters. You can increase your chances of winning by adding useful cards to your play area. Venture into dangerous ruins, search them thoroughly, and defeat waves of enemies to become a legendary treasure hunter!

name.value: The Curious Case of the Disappeared Decktet card

item.description:
HELP! One of the cards from the original decktet has been stolen. You are on the case, like the good detective you are. The rich reward and eternal glory certainly are good motivations. Unfortunately you are not the only detective who's after the card. This makes the investigation difficult at least. 
The answers you get from your fellow detectives are ambiguous and enigmatic. So... it's up to you to find the missing card first.

This is the first Decktet deduction game. All 2-9 cards but one have been dealt out. The cards in this game all show at least 4 characteristics: one rank, two suits and one type (location, personality or event). On your turn choose two characteristics you would like to know more about. Ask the other players how many times these characteristics appear on their cards. As a detective, you will find it's just a matter of elimination. It's all quite logical...

item.description:
Pirates of Gold Cove is a trick-taking card game for the whole family. New players will find the game easy to play with waves of fun for everyone. Weathered card players will enjoy the strategy of play, as vast as the deep blue sea.

The player that is dealt the ship starts the game, and each other player matches the color if they can, trying to take the trick with the highest numbered card of that color. There are cards that you want to capture for more points like treasure maps, chests, and gold coins. There is even one card that you want to avoid capturing, the dreaded Magistrate Burns. Once all the cards have been played and all tricks taken, the player that captured the Duchess Carmen receives the cards that were removed from the game, and perhaps even more points. Players total their points and are paid in gold and silver coins. Once all the coins are given out, the player with the most treasure is the winner.

The game includes high-quality plastic coated playing cards and a sack full of gold and silver coins. Whimsical characters illustrated by Monte Moore in bright colors make the game as attractive as it is fun.

name.value: San Guo Sha: Tomb of Cao Cao

item.description:
UNAUTHORIZED PRODUCTION

 
 
 The information that BGG has on this item indicates that San Guo Sha is an unauthorized reproduction of BANG! with just a few differences, published in China and distributed in several coutries of the world.

 


Scattered artifacts of the Legends of the Three Kingdoms lay hidden in Cao Cao's tomb. Find and reassemble the artifact fragments to unlock the power stored within for a millennium! 
What secret is hidden in the tomb? Who can master the hidden power in the artifacts?

After Cao Cao's tomb was discovered, the explorers delve into the tomb to unlock Cao Cao's secret . The players will look for artifacts in the tomb through exploration of the debris, excavation or exchange with other explorers. The artifacts wield special power, and will aid in further exploration of the tomb. The first player to complete five artifacts wins the game.

Though this takes place in the San Guo Sha game setting, this is a stand-alone game of drawing tiles. Treasure and junk tiles will be placed face down in the middle of the table. Players will draw two tiles, and keep one. Then players will trade one of their own face-down tiles with the face-down tile of another player. The object is to be the first to collect the right tiles that will assemble the lost treasures.

The game comes with:
 60 artifact tiles
 4 character tiles
 1 drawstring bag

item.description:
Teachatot is designed to help children learn simple spelling and arithmetic. Select a picture card and asking the child, whose turn it is, to find and identify the letters making up the word for the picture. Similarly, you could select a number and the child must find the numbers needed to make that total. Get the most right after an equal number of turns, and you win

All the 144 pieces interlock with each other to provide lots of word combinations and arithmetic sums.

The game was first produced in Britain in the 1950's but sank without trace. However, it has now resurfaced in Australia/New Zealand, and has been available there for some time.

Players draw cards where (German) first names have been creatively transformed into some weird word conglomeration.

Actual examples from the German game: Weichangst for Hartmut, Hirschweitkaffee for Renate (Reh-nah-Tee)

An English example off the top of my head (so non-German speakers get the idea): Buddhaout for Christin

The goal is to correctly decipher as many of the first names behind them as possible. Turns are timed with a sand timer.

item.description:
Quiz game who pinched the name from a different American game related to $64,000. the names are the same but the games are completely different. The 64,000 Question is a party game where guests are asked quiz questions. No board, no playing pieces, just question cards. This game has a board and playing pieces.

Up to four players attempt to get 10 questions correct and thus reach the spinner in the middle of the box. The spinner itself is used to determine the 'colour' of the question you have to face.

The questions are intended for children to answer, not adults.

Statistical ice hockey game. A few dice rolls and the result is known, at that speed you can play a whole season within a couple of days.

All the Stanley Cup teams are rated, both as teams and as individual players.

It comes in the usual Valgames' pouch.

In MafiaDollar each player takes control of a mafia clan and tries to earn as many dollars as possible before the "End of Prohibition" card appears. Players employ gangsters, equip them with item cards, and send them out to the street to "earn" dollars by taking loot cards and bringing them safely back to their warehouses. If the streets are empty, it might be a good time to break into another player's warehouse or take out one of the competing gangsters. Beware of the police, however, as they might pop into a player's hand at any time and turn their forces your way.

At the end of the game, the clan who banks the most dollars wins!

Football game with dice.
There are 7 dice in this game and player rolls these on his turn.
Different dice have different faces like: passing, defencing, corner kick, fault, shot a goal, penalty and players do the actions according to dice.

A game consists of two half-time of three minutes. Players with the most goals at the end of the game is the winner

Descriptions from Kickstarter:

A Las Barricadas is a boardgame about conflict between two opposing social forces, namely that of the state and of anti-authoritarian demonstrators. It is a two-player game with each player representing one of these social forces, the theatre of this conflict being that of the street demonstration. It is being developed and designed by the Black Flag Games collective, committed to the idea that games and interactive media can have an impact in the struggle for a free and cooperative world. We are also committed to the ideals of free culture and aim to deliver professional play experiences that enrich a participatory entertainment culture.

'A Las Barricadas' is a two-player, asymmetric boardgame. This means it is a contest between two players whose ability to affect the game is different. Play takes place on a board which represents a real city or historic location, and small chips are placed on building squares (buildings can be occupied, blockaded or vandalized). The Radical player chooses randomly from a small deck of objective cards and both players choose their tactics for the game. Victory is achieved by the Radical player if they complete their objectives in an allotted number of rounds. The Police player only gets a small piece of flavor text as a hint to the objectives of the radical player, and their objective is to keep the radical player from gaining victory points and completing their goals. Many of the objectives relate to acquiring Strike chips (by causing economic loss through blockades, pickets, occupations etc.) or by gaining Media chips (representing media coverage).

It's your lifelong dream – to join the Star Patrol and be part of the crew of an interstellar Starship. You've worked hard, graduated from the academy, and received your first assignment as part of a team of young recruits, confident in your training and ready to be put to the test. Nothing can possibly go wrong as you are prepared for anything...

You are the Space Cadets.

Space Cadets is a fun and frantic cooperative game for 3-6 players who take on the roles of Bridge Officers of a Starship. Each officer must accomplish his specific task in order for the team to successfully complete the mission. You might be the...


 Helmsman, plotting the ship's course through asteroid fields and nebulae. 
 Engineer, using dominoes to get enough power to each system. 
 Weapons Officer, completing puzzles to load the torpedoes and flicking a disc down a track to launch them.
 Shield Officer, using tiles to form poker hands to get the strongest shields. 
 Sensor Officer, using your sense of touch to scan and lock on enemy targets. 
 Captain, setting the plan and making sure that everyone stays focused and does their job. 


If your crew can work together to accomplish the mission goals, you just might make it home in one piece.

link.value: Space Cadets: Resistance Is Mostly Futile

item.description:
The game of Bird Cage is a connection game in which players attempt to connect their sides of a square by establishing an unbroken connection in a rectangular (but staggered) grid.

The game's original incarnation was as a machine built by the game's designer, noted engineer Claude Shannon. The machine would choose its' move by measuring electrical resistance between its' sides of the square and would reportedly win "almost always" when making the first move.

The game was later re-discovered independently by mathematician David Gale, who got it published under the name of Bridg-It.

Bird Cage has since been defined as an abstract game called the Shannon Switching Game, playable on any finite graph. In the abstract game, two players, Short and Cut, will either attempt to connect two predetermined points on the graph (short) by claiming edges, or remove graph edges (Cut) such that the two points cannot be linked.

name.value: Angry Birds: Spring is in the Air

item.description:
This game one of the many games in the Angry Birds Series.

"Spring is popping and the birds will have their revenge!" The third in the "build and destroy" series of hands-on Angry Birds games, this stand-alone game includes 1 red bird, 1 white bird, 3 pigs, 2 sets of bunny ears, 2 crackable eggs, mission cards, a "slingshot" (catapult), and an assortment of girders.

Players score points by using the birds and the slingshot to destroy the structure designated by the mission card.

This game was launched as a Target exclusive.

Australian promotional game, published by a bank.

The game is a simple roll-and-move game. Obey instructions when you land on a coloured square (Green is good but red is bad).

First player to get from Home to the Bank, wins.

name.value: Ma Boîte à réactions: Monsieur Madame

item.description:
A game of reaction. Players turn the cards on the board, if they recognize a character from the card, all players must make the appropriate response: laughter, falling, tickle etc.

Whenever you're the first to give the right answer, you will receive a rubber stamp on your scoresheet. 10 shots and You win the game.

Each player has a spaceship marker that comes on the board by one edge.

In his turn player places a tile that will advance his marker on the board, creating a path. Also players must avoid asteroids flying on the board.

The goal is to remain on the board last and therefore push his opponents off the set by forcing their path out of bounds.

This game is an adaptation of Tsuro with a new twist: Asteroids will disrupt things.

item.description:
A battery operated British game of chance, no skill required at all.

The board has a wheel with nine different coloured horses with jockeys on board. Players are invited to place their bets. You could play for real money or buttons. When all the bets are placed, you flick a switch and the wheel will spin. As each horse goes past a connection, their colour light flashes on, so with a fast spinning wheel, the lights all flash, adding to the excitement. When the wheel stops, there will be one light on and that is the race winner. Winning punters collect their bets and another race can start.

The winner is the one player who has the most money when the game ends.

Three dimensional abstract game. The board is plastic and stands between the players (as the Connect 4 board does). In a turn, a player may either:
Drop a disc into the board; or...
Move the current discs by operating a slide at the side.

Thus, you may add to the board or manipulte discs already in the board.

The winner is the first player to get three discs of their colour in a row.

Action game. The board is three dimensional and involves chutes to take a ball from one chute to another. A ball is dropped in the top and will work itself down to the bottom where, hopefully, it will score points depending in which hole it eventually settles.

It seems to me that there is very little skill in this. You cannot decide to throw it down the chutes with gusto, nor can you try to make it a very gentle roll. The different direction chutes take out any influence a player might have, and the end result is purely a matter of chance. Children will enjoy it though, at least until the novelty wears off.

The winner is the player with the most points at the end of the game.

The box has this slogan....
'Roll - a - ball
Down - a - hill
Try your luck
Test your skill'

Fatum is a fast-moving civilization game set in the year 600 BC in the world of ancient regions around the Mediterranean Sea. Each player is in the role of a king whose task is to bring prosperity to his lands: alleviate famine and plague, establish trade routes, build alliances, found new cities and improve culture, defend or expand his territory and secure peace. But first he must win favour and support of capricious divinities…

Players choose different actions (building, fighting, trading etc.) which, directly or indirectly, bring them victory points. Their starting positions are different, but well balanced. Strategic planning and a bit of divine benevolence could turn each of them into one of the most glorious rulers of ancient times!

From the publisher:

Field of Glory Napoleonic is written in an approachable and easy-to-learn manner to allow players to concentrate on realistic deployments and battlefield tactics of the early modern era. FOGN will cater for both types of player, with a full point system allowing theoretical battles between balanced armies to be played out, as well as accommodating factual scenarios. The rulebook will maintain the same production values as previous FOG and FOGR releases and will be designed both to explain the game and be a reference guide when playing. To make the rules easier to follow, we will include examples, detailed descriptions and explanations of unusual situations in a similar way to our Ancients and Renaissance rulebooks.

Based on the core mechanics of its predecessors, Field of Glory: Napoleonic is a tabletop miniatures game that allows players to command the armies of any of the nations involved in the Napoleonic and French Revolutionary Wars, emphasizing the combined arms tactics that dominated the battlefields of the period. Players will deploy cavalry, infantry, and artillery units to move, fire and assault their way to victory.

item.description:
Enchanters of Legamoria is a free print-and-play fantasy game that combines the strategic aspects of chess with the dynamics of magic the gathering. Designed for 2, 4 or 6 players, the game is played on a grid where opponents take turns summoning pieces, modifiers, lands and spells to the battleground. Pieces have various attacks, abilities and effects that, when used in concert with each other, produce infinite variations of duels. Each player may summon up to 4 lands in his/her summoning ground. The game ends when a player or team has no more remaining lands on the board.

The game files are located at legamoria.com. Enjoy!

Players take turns saying positive integers less than or equal to 8, but not equal to the number the previous player said, or 9 minus that number, and adding or subtracting that number to a running total. The goal is to be the first player to pass through all ten "hoops" (multiples of 10) up to and including 100. There are two ways to pass through a hoop (a) by saying a number that will reach the opposite side by an equal amount (e.g., if you are at 28, saying 4 will take you through hoop 30 to 32) or (b) by saying a number that lands you in the hoop, and then exiting by the same number on the following turn. If you miss, or are blocked, go back and try again, but you're only allowed to miss the final goal of 100 one time, or else you lose.

One variant allows players an extra move immediately after passing a hoop.

As new villains appear to lay claim to the world of Indines, new heroes rise to challenge them. BattleCON: Devastation of Indines puts you in control of 30 mighty heroes and deadly villains to decide the fate of the world.

BattleCON: Devastation of Indines is a standalone dueling card game designed for head-to-head and team play. Each player selects a character who uses a unique gameplay mechanism to give them an edge in combat. Take control of guitar-playing summoner, a pair of tag-teaming werewolves, a prodigal paladin, a genius artificer, and more! Each character's play style requires new strategies, but uses the same foundational tactics, making a new character easy to learn, but challenging to master.

Players move along a seven-space-long board, trading blows and attempting to strike the opponent, using attacks formed by combining a character's unique styles and abilities with a set of basic cards that all characters share. The last player standing wins!

BattleCON: Devastation of Indines can be played on its own or combined with BattleCON: War of Indines to create an even greater pool of characters and play variants.

Included with the game: BattleQUEST Guide

The BattleQUEST Dungeon Guide contains six adventures (3 solo and 3 cooperative) for players. Using BattleQUEST, players can play alone or cooperatively against automated enemies in an attempt to defeat the final boss and claim victory!

item.description: YUM is a real-time pattern recognition game where players use an identical startup deck of round cards of different ice cream flavors and must build the proper ice cream cones, in a central location. Once a player believes a cone is complete he selects the cone card and flips it along with all his used ice cream cards. Players can clock-out for additional points once they feel that their remaining ice cream cards can't build more cones, leaving the last player without bonus points. Players verify their cones and discard all incorrect cone cards. All ice cream cards are used again and more rounds are played until the deck of cones is depleated.

link.value: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

name.value: No Lo Testeamos Ni Un Poco: Legados

item.description:
You may be familiar with our very silly card game "We Didn't Playtest This at All". It is silly, quick, and fun. We have an interesting idea on how to expand it: designing a version of Playtest that benefits from you writing on the cards!

What's new about Legacies cards (compared to original We Didn't Playtest This at All cards) is they contain a slot for Owner and a picture. When you win a game of Playtest: Legacies, you claim ownership of the last card you played, by writing your name in the Owner box. FOREVER. If you own a card, you ignore it if it ever tells you that you lose.

Playtest: Legacies is a full stand-alone game (60 cards plus mystery packs). It may also be combined with the original "We didn't Playtest This At All" and its expansions.

item.description:
A game that combines a drinking game with top trumps. After winning a hand (as in top trumps) the winner also has to take a drink.

Players pit their selected characters against each other on qualities such as 'Favourite tipple' and 'Special skills' to determine points scored, with losers downing their respective drinks and a special forfeit forcing them to drink the 'Dirty Pint' (when players draw a hand all the drinks are poured into one glass, the 'Dirty Pint').

33 playing cards feature a charismatic illustration of a variety of parodies of notoriously drinkers, such as the WAG, Abby Goodnight, and Prime Minister, Wineston Burphill.

Absolution is a cooperative game for Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game. To quote the designer:
I like cooperative games, especially "Shadows Over Camelot" by Serge Laget and Bruno Cathala, so I designed Absolution as a cooperative adventure with a Stonehenge theme. Similarly to "Shadows Over Camelot," I wanted Absolution to be difficult, but not impossible to win with the right strategy among the players. Many Stonehenge scholars can agree upon two points: It looks like some sort of astronomical clock, and people died there. In Absolution, the clock is ticking. Whether anyone dies tonight will be determined by you. Save the Druid!

The usual "no telling what your cards are" rule for collaborative games applies. Utilizing a central exchange field to swap cards, players try to set up their hands to be able to play a single card that matches the current turn number (1–30), or a pair of cards whose sum or difference equals the turn number. Your success at doing this determines the pace at which the poor druid walks to the altar to be sacrificed. Don't let it happen!

Absolution is an official game for Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game.

The board is comprised of 25 posts arranged in a 5x5 array. Players take turns placing one ball of their color on any post on the board. The winner is the first to get five balls of their color in a straight line - this can be accomplished vertically (on the same post), horizontally or diagonally.

From the instruction book - 
Cinco: The newly designed game employing 25 pegs for 109 possible win positions. This fascinating game of strategy gives endless hours of pleasure and excitement.

Similar to:

 Score Four

Looks like it might be an abstract game but turns out to be only luck-based.

The object of the game is to travel from your outer star to the inner one. To do this a player must try to communicate with the other players telepathically. This is attempted by another player drawing a card from the deck and you have to identify it by only the power of the mind. Five such attempts (i.e. guesses) are allowed and the fewer used mean that you move further along the board in your journey to the centre.

Battlefield Auerstadt 1806 is cardgame for battle of Auerstadt in Napoleonic wars. This game issued with self-published version Game Journal magazine volume 42.

The game use three types of cards, unit , commander and action card. The unit card represent divisions of French and Prussian army. The commander card represent French commander Davout and Prussian commander Duke of Brunswick.ã€€The action card represent various military actions and terrain.

In each turn, players can perform one free action and can also play action card for perform additional actions.

Winner determine by advantage number or elimination of opponent. The advantage represent control of battlefield and can improve by die roll test in each turn.

Aus Dem Traum (From the Dream in German) is operational level wargame for battle for the Bulge in World War 2.

Players control either German Army or Allied Army, and manage movement and combat. The game sequence is standard movement, combat and secondary movement. However, several actions such a move more than one hex, secondary movement or combined attack are require to use operational point. Operational point is given few points per turn.

Winner determined by control of cities and crossing the Meuse river by German units.

Game Scale: 
1 division, brigade, regiment per unit
9 km per hex
1 day per game turn.

SPIKE is a game of beach volleyball for two teams of two players. It is played on a square grid board, with a 4x8 court in the centre.

Players move on the grid by playing cards numbered from 1 to 5. The higher the card value, the further they can travel to receive the ball - but also the more inaccurate their pass. Most cards have symbols that allow special actions, e.g. Spike, Dig or Block.

The basic game is played with four preset decks, but in Tournament Mode each player can customise their deck to reflect their strategy and individual playing style by focusing on speed, power, accuracy...

Partners are not allowed to communicate during rallies, except by selecting a Blocking Strategy card that is hidden to their opponents.

As play progresses and points are scored, players remove cards from their decks, resulting in a boost at first as the weaker cards are weeded out, and representing fatigue and predictability in the end-game, where fewer options are available.

The winner is the first team to score 11 points, or 21 in Tournament Mode.

item.description:
Battle For Souls is a card game pitting the seven archangels of heaven versus the seven princes of hell in a fight for the eternal souls of humankind.

In the game, 1, 2, or 4 players choose the side of heaven or the side of hell. Each side will battle for 28 souls, which are worth victory points. Players add holy or unholy points on the souls in play based on how they use temptation, virtue, sin, intercession, holy relic, unholy relic, angel and devil cards. Earn enough holy points, and when the soul is reaped it goes to heaven, earning the side of good victory points; earn enough unholy points, and when the soul is reaped it goes to hell, earning the side of evil victory points. If a soul does not earn enough holy or unholy points and is reaped, it goes to purgatory where its victory points are not counted.

Guiding a soul to complete purity or complete darkness before death and final judgment adds a new archangel or prince of hell to a player's arsenal. Influence on souls can be spent for more powerful cards that have special abilities, and allow a player to gain souls more quickly.

Many strategic decisions impact play. Strategies include focusing on gaining more help from heaven or hell to increase your power, working to reap souls quickly from the start with little intervention from the angelic and demonic hordes, or balancing your play to ensure victory.

Sin, Intercession, and Relic cards can be purchased for beneficial effects at the cost of holy and unholy points. These help to make for deep gameplay and excellent risk-reward scenarios. Invest in these cards to strengthen your position.

item.description: Players take one of 4 included pieces (Foo, Whom, Wumbus and the Grinch) and using a spinner move them according to the color that they spin. Once on a space they take the included fishing pole and try to catch what look like whales from the fishing pond to help move them along. First player to cross the finish line wins.

Democracy: Majority Rules is a game of debate, diplomacy and deal-making from Mark Rein•Hagen of Vampire: The Masquerade and Werewolf: The Apocalypse fame. Mark has taken his love and study of politics to create a game of power struggles, back door deals, and unscrupulous actions.

You play an activist, a power broker, or the leader of a political party – in any case, someone who organizes campaigns, games the system and wins elections. Your job is to make compromises, yet always stand by your principles, form coalitions yet still achieve your agenda. To succeed you must herd cats, spin facts into a web of deception, and speak truth to power.

Enter a world of mudslinging, dirty tricks and the crooks and liars who manipulate the masses, juke the system and corrupt the true believers in order to throw out the tyrants, make the world a better place, and save us all from ourselves. A canny and calculating political operative, you are battling to take over a country in crisis. The old-line political parties are weak and divided, primed for being taken over from within or pushed out of the way. Your movement has captured the imagination of a small but loyal few and now it's your job to grow it into a national force. The goal is to put your handpicked candidate into high office, lead the country, and put your mark on history.

Democracy: Majority Rules is focused on the retail work of politics at every scale: making friends, forging alliances, outmaneuvering rivals, deceiving enemies, building consensus, selling your point of view, creating a coalition, hiding resentment, feigning weakness, blindsiding foes, and turning doubters into believers. It's all in the game.

While the game plays 3-5, there is a Party Expansion pack that adds extra components, super supporters worth five normal supporters, and enough materials for up to 15 people. Currently, the Party Expansion is available only on the Kickstarter campaign.

item.description:
On a small gameboard the players have to us their piece to create a row of four.

Playing pieces for are shaped like egg timers. Each player has a side based on the color of the egg timers which are red and green.

There are 4 hexagonal and 4 round timers of each colour. There are 4 smooth topped times and 4 rough top times of each colour.

The object of the game is to create a row of four timers with the same feature.
 - Identical by colour, so 4 reds or 4 greens.
 - Identical by shape, so 4 round, or 4 hex.
 - Identical by surface, so 4 with a smooth surface or 4 with a rough surface.

Taking turns each player places one of his timers (i.e. his color) on the board.

If at one point a row of 4 timers with at least one identical feature (i.e. color, shape, or surface texture) is created, then the game is over and the winner is the player that formed the line of four.

name.value: het huis Anubis: De weg der verdoemden

item.description: Adventurous and challenging! Dare to go on an adventure without fear on the road of the reprobates. Find your own special powercard by using your cards very smart. Beware! You will see only the cards from your opponenents and they see your cards. In order to know which cards you held you try to ask smart questions as much as possible. When you've found your powercards turn your summary so only you can see them and than you can go directly to the road of the reprobates. If you are the first who enters the road of the reprobates, you win the game.

Spone is a game for two players (White and Black) playable with a Shibumi set.

Start: The board starts with four red balls in the inner 2x2 square on the board level.

Play: Players take turns either placing a ball of their color to any playable point or entering a ball of their color from the side on non board levels, pushing other balls. The entry may cause a drop but may not push any balls off the board.

End: When the pyramid is complete, White wins if the greatest group (white or black) on the surface is even, Black wins if it is odd.

Ties are not possible.

item.description:
Implementing a deck of cards, some dice and a pocketful of loose change, take control of a Zombie Horde and work to overrun a Survivor Safehouse before you are exterminated!

The solo player divides a standard playing card deck into face cards and number cards, dealing relevant cards into piles representing the Survivors and their Safehouse, Items, and Zombies. The player, as the Zombies, then attacks the Survivors in an attempt to wear their numbers down until no Survivors remain.

It is a game of chance and skill, and very portable. Check out the files section for the full extended rules, a quick-reference printable version (which folds up to fit in your pack of cards), and an extraneous (but helpful) flowchart of gameplay (because flowcharts make the world a better place.)

Relatively recently added: Alternate card faces for all numbered cards representing both items and zombies, as well as zombified jacks, queens, kings, aces and jokers.

1941: THE WORLD IS AT WAR!

Quick and Convenient: Axis & Allies 1941 is designed to be set up and played more quickly than any previous A&A game. In essence, this is a simplified A&A experience that will introduce players to the A&A mechanics and play style. Play time runs between 1.5 to 2 hours.

Familiar Mechanics: This game utilizes the A&A game mechanics present in A&A 1942 2nd Edition, as designed by Larry Harris (the creator of the original game).

New Units: A key feature for enfranchised players is an entirely new set of unit sculpts. There are 16 all-new designs such as the P-40 Warhawk, Tiger Tank, AVRO Lancaster, FW-190, IS-2 tank, HMS Hood, He-111, and the Akagi Aircraft Carrier. These playing pieces can be used in any other A&A game, and will be desirable to players who seek to expand their A&A collections.

Game Overview

Five major powers struggle for supremacy. Germany and Japan are aligned against the great alliance of the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union, and the United States.

Designed for 2–5 players, the game is set in 1941: The Axis has great momentum and is expanding its conquests in both Europe and Asia.

Controlling one of the Axis or Allied powers, you will command both your country’s military forces and its war-time economy. Show that you are a brilliant military strategist by planning your attacks, marshaling your forces into embattled territories, and resolving the conflicts.Victory goes to the side that conquers its opponents on the field of battle and liberates or occupies the greatest cities of the world. Change the course of history in a few short hours!

item.description:
System for replaying individual football matches by minute-to-minute decisions. Statistics for all the 1990 World Cup teams are included, as it is a system for translating statistics from any match, so you can replay that great day for your team (unless your team is England, so there is no great day you can recreate!).

Each team is rated for ability in certain skills like 'shooting at goal' or 'passing the ball', 'movement' and so on. Once you decide the option you would like to take, you roll the dice and check on the ability. Sometimes you will retain possession and thus make the next decision, and so on, until you lose the ball and your opponent has the same choices for his team.

The one who scores the most goals, wins.

From the box: "Playful Malice is a conversational frolic for adult adults - a game in which players compare views of one another's quirks. The purpose of the game is to have fun - and, incidentally, to see who wins the most chips."

On a round, one person is called the "Target". The Target takes one of the 64 cards from the deck and reads it aloud. He reads the statements one at a time, giving players time to rate each item on their score pads from 0 to 5. The Target also rates his own personality.

Now the Target will guesses aloud how each player rated him, and depending if he is near or far from the ratings he will receive chips. The player with the most chips is the winner.

Buffy Trivia Game is the test of your knowledge of Buffy the Vampire Slayer!

In their continuing struggle against the forces of evil, Buffy and her friends must defeat a selection of vampires and demons particularly formidable. Boxes 'quiz' brighten the path to test the knowledge of the players on the main characters and key events in the series. Each correct answer and defeated demon can accumulate points throughout the game. Issues affect all the episodes of the first 5 seasons.

The winner of the game is the first player or team to reach the finish and successfully face the last vampire.

link.value: TV Series: Buffy the Vampire Slayer

item.description:
Cedric like to be photographed with Chen, his girlfriend. But Chen agreed only if he pass a perfect day to be a good boy. He must collect points to charm the girl and then run to the place where she waits to be photographed with him.

There is a journey through the day of Cedric on the gameboard. Beginning with the square "Start of the day" and ending with the square "end of the day" where players is able to pose with Chen.

In his turn player rolls the color die and move his game-piece 
to next square with rolled color. Then he may pass a test to roll a number dice and get a result greater or equal than the number on the box. If the test is successful he adds the points he has just won the score noted on their file and writes it on the notes (with erasable marker).

Each player has 3 event cards he may use in his turn to help provide bonuses to its dice rolls.

The first player who reaches the finish square and pose with Chen is the winner.

A free print and play dice game based off Shaun Derrick's excellent World Cup Game.

Moving the footballing battlefield from the World Cup to the UEFA European Championships, 2-4 players can print off tournament sheets for Euro '96 in England, Euro 2000 in Belgium/Netherlands and Euro 2004 in Portugal.

Set up is simple. Print off one A4 tournament sheet and the rules sheet. Grab six dice (preferably one red, one blue, one green, one yellow and two others). Find a pencil. You're ready to go.

The teams in the tournament will be divided out between the players who will then choose the dice they want to roll and designate the dice roll results to the teams, scoring goals, defending, scoring penalties and competing to get their teams through to the quarter finals, semi finals and ultimately the final to compete for the Championship trophy!

The European Championship Dice Game is designed to be highly portable with a short play time. Perfect to take on trips or to whip out during lunch breaks.

Object of the game is to get your name in history by winning the amazing race of Isla Bananas. The winner will receive the prestigious Cup of Bananas.

The race takes place across six islands.
To reach each island, players fly at a certain speed and it will be determined by the sum of the dice that players secretly launched away from their dice cups.
If the speed is less then demanded player can't reach another island. If the speed is more the player risk to crash with his flying machine.

item.description:
Introduction

Konobi is a drawless connection game for two players: Black and White. It's played on the intersections (points) of a square board, which is initially empty. The top and bottom edges of the board are colored black; the left and right edges are colored white.

				
					Definitions

Two like-colored stones are strongly connected if they are orthogonally adjacent to each other, and weakly connected if they are diagonally adjacent to each other without sharing any strongly connected neighbor. Note that two stones of different colors are never considered to be connected.

A chain is a set of connected stones.

				
					Play

Starting with Black, the players take turns placing stones of their own color on empty points of the board, one stone per turn.

It's illegal to make a weak connection to a certain stone unless it's impossible to make a placement which is both strongly connected to that stone and not weakly connected to another.

It's also illegal to form a crosscut, i.e. a 2x2 pattern of stones consisting of two diagonally adjacent Black stones and two diagonally adjacent White stones.

If a player can't make a move on his turn, he must pass. Passing is otherwise not allowed. There will always be a move available to at least one of the players.

The game is won by the player who completes a chain of his color touching the two opposite board edges of his color. Draws are not possible.

				
					Pie rule

The pie rule is used in order to make the game fair. This means that White will have the option, on his first turn only, to change sides instead of making a regular move.

item.description:
6th century BC, China does not yet have a name and seven kingdoms are fighting the mandate of heaven: the right to rule over the rising empire.

The game turn consists of nine phases. Those are moving priors, development, production, policy, recruitment, commercial, Science, movement (and battles), counts during the player move his game-pieces, take actions according the cards or draw tiles.

During the counts, player must feed itself and pay the balance of forces. Each province not be able to eat or pay will receive a token of revolt. After 2 tokens of revolt, player loses that province.
Also players earn civilization points during this phase.
1 point per province owned 
1 point per occupied capital
1 point per level of development in most developed
1 point for general
3 points per wall funded
-1 Point for each pair of tokens of revolt

The game ends after one player has accumulated at least 50 points. Whoever has the most points wins.

Oddly enough, several of you have been hired to build the city of OddVille, home to four powerful worker guilds.

Cleverly place your buildings in order to obtain greater power and fame, while thwarting your opponents' plans. Manage your workers to obtain the resources, coins, and building projects you need in order to make your mark on the city. Plan the city streets to get access to resources or coins from nearby buildings, even if not yours.

Impress the right guild, and you will get a visit from a guild member, who will gladly help you out while enjoying your hospitality. The guild comes first, though: At a moment's notice, every guild member will return to the guild hall, regardless of how much that inconveniences you. Of course, the person who "inspired" the guild meeting may be chuckling gleefully at the "unfortunate" timing of your guest's departure.

OddVille is a card-based city-building game in which all actions are carried out by playing one of your four Worker cards. Each Worker card has a different power and can be used in different ways: to get a project, to obtain resources, or to collect coins. During your turn, you can either play a card or add a building to the city. Connect it to adjacent buildings with roads and you will gain their bonus.

The city grows with each player's contribution, ever changing the values of players' buildings. As soon as a player builds his sixth building, the game ends and the player with the most points wins.

item.description:
From Warlord Games website:

"Pike & Shotte is Warlord Games' third rulebook publication. It is a beautiful book in its own right with hundreds of colour photo of the most exquisitely painted model soldiers taken from the world s foremost collections. The rule book's intention is to inspire a collector to play gentlemanly games with their collections of soldiers with friends where the emphasis is on the spirit of the period, not the letter of the rule. It is a hearty publication and not for nitpickers or miseries. There are some good gags in it, but it also plays well and enables players to conduct a very big battle in a reasonable period of time, leaving them more time to chat about the highs and lows and what ifs..."

Pike & Shotte closes the gap that Warlord Games left between the "Hail Caesar" and the "Black Powder" rulebooks. Using the hallmark Warlord Games orders system (a player must state what his units are about to do, then make a leadership roll dice to check the efficiency with whom of the order given is received), with a 3-phases turn modality that clearly brings the Rick Priestley firm, the game is very smooth, fast and less detailed and mechanic than its stronger competitor, the Field of Glory Renaissance system.

Disaster on Kangchenjunga (or "K13" for short) is the third game in Tom Decker's 'Disaster on' series.

A plane has crashed high up on the slopes of Kangchenjunga, the world’s third highest mountain. One of the passengers was carrying plans that contain secrets that if exposed or delivered into the wrong hands, could threaten world security. Your nation has sent you to join an expedition intent on reaching the summit of Kangchenjunga (Kangch), but you have different orders. You must reach the plane wreck, find the secret plans, and continue the expedition as if you are just one of the team. However, there is a spy among you who will try to sabotage your efforts and steal the plans away from you. There may also be another nation’s team on the mountain with similar interests. It’s a race to the plane crash!

The game begins at midnight at High Camp on Kangch. You will control the movements for your entire team, most of whom are trying to reach the summit. Each turn, you will move climbers towards the summit (and plane crash) and then back down again. However, at some point in the game, the spy will be revealed, changing the rules drastically and forcing you to make decisions about who will summit, who will find and protect the secret plans, and who will try to just survive!

Your decisions will not only determine the lives of your climbers, but may also stop the Cold War from heating up. Think you have what it takes? Play Disaster on Kangchenjunga to find out!

name.value: UNO: Limited Too It's A Girl's World

item.description:
From the box: Pack your bags and get ready for fun with the Limited Too edition of Uno! 110 Custom Cards featuring the Limited Too crew exploring their favorite cities with their best friends. Same great Uno play plus the exclusive Around the World card that allows players to travel to a new place and gain an edge on their opponents.

Summary: Just like standard Uno. The Around the World card allows you to swap all hands left, right or across, player's choice, and also choose the color like a Wild card.

User summary: Roll and advance along a board by answering Bible trivia questions. Questions have three levels of difficulty. Game also has Gift and Peril cards that can reward or hinder your progress. Other spaces cause you to change spaces with another player or roll again. Game board also has a bridge that can be used as a shortcut, but you have to roll the correct number. First player to finish wins.

Bling Bling Gemstone features the same game play as Justin Oh's Toc Toc Woodman, but now players have more to aim for when they're swinging the axe.

To set up the game, players create a pillar of discs, with each disc having four colored plastic "gem" pieces slid into notches on its side. On a player's turn, the player takes two swings at the disc tower with a plastic pickaxe. If any gems or discs fall from the tower, the player must keep them. Red gems are worth 3 points, pink gems 2, and transparent gems 1, while the center disc is worth -10 points.

When no gems remain in the tower, the game ends and the player with the most points wins!

item.description: One of a series of Wit trivia games, National Park Wit has 105 cards with questions about National Parks. On the back of each card is a different photo from a National Park and a point value from 1-10 and 15. On the front of each card are three trivia questions and answers, as well as a description of the picture on the back. In turn, each player is asked a question of the asker's choice from the three on the card. If he gets the question right, he keeps the card. If he gets it wrong, all other players in turn (except the question reader) are given a chance. If all fail, the card is placed in the so-called "stumper" pile. After all cards have been asked, the stumper pile is revisited. Then, all players add up their points and he with the highest points wins.

One of a series of Wit trivia games, Yellowstone Wit has 105 cards with questions about Yellowstone. On the back of each card is a photo of something found in Yellowstone (Lower Falls, Old Faithful, brown bear, Mammoth Hot Springs, big horn sheep, Morning Glory Pool, elk, Castle Geyser, bison, a meadow, geyser, stagecoach and hotel, swan and mud pot) and a point value from 1-10 or 15. On the front of each card is a trivia question and answer. In turn, each player is asked a question. If he gets the question right, they keep the card. If he gets it wrong, all other players in turn (except the question reader) are given a chance. If all fail, the card is placed in the so-called "stumper" pile. After all cards have been asked, the stumper pile is revisited. Then, all players add up their points and he with the highest points wins.

"Lulu circus" in English.

Each player receives a different illustration representing the circus spectacle.
They must find all the misplaced items.
A player draw a tile with an item.
Each player must then find it in his picture as soon as possible.
The first who shout "Given Lulu!" wins the tile.

The player who has the most tiles when all objects were found wins the game.

item.description:
Who will be the best fisherman?

Fish or worms? In his turn, players tries catch some fish with a fishing rod. You may get fish but You may get worms.
They roll dice and the color determine the fish: goldfish, yellow, blue, green or purple fish? To win the fishing contest, you must be the first to catch 5 fish.

Abstract game. There are 16 plastic triangular pieces and each turn you must add one to the table in Triominos fashion, that is, one against another, but not just matching numbers you must also match colours.

First person to use all their dominos, wins.

Players is building the castle by playing cards.

In his turn player places his cards on the table to match the colors on cards already placed for scoring maximum points.

He scores as many points how long is the edge of the castle in this color

The winner is the player who scores the most points at the end of the game.

Wits & Wagers Party, a simplified version of the most award-winning party game in history, comes with 250 of the best questions from the out-of-print Wits & Wagers Expansion Pack 1. These questions were chosen because they are lighter and more fun than the questions from the original Wits & Wagers, making this the best edition to play with your non-gamer friends and family. The poker chips in this edition are twice as heavy and thick as those from the original W&W.

How to Play
1) Someone reads a question.
2) Everyone writes down a guess.
3) The guesses are placed face up on the table and ordered smallest to largest.
4) Players place their Betting Tokens on the guess they think is closest to the right answer.

Players score one poker chip for a correct bet or for having the closest guess. On the seventh and final question, players can bet their poker chips. The player with the most poker chips after this question wins.

item.description:
Barrier is similar to Ludo/Pachisi. It is a roll and move game in which you try to get all your counters round the board before your opponents, however you can also use your counters to form barriers (by stacking multiple counters on top of each other). Forming a barrier blocks your opponents from moving past until they roll an exact number (which reduces your barrier by 1). The downside of this is that your barrier counters can not move, but can be disbanded at any time.

The game is played in teams of 2, and your roll can count for either you or your partner. Partners must be formed form opposite colours (i.e. red & yellow, blue & green, orange & purple). Both partners can contribute to a single barrier or create separate barriers. Landing on an opponents counter sends it back to the start.

The strategy of the game revolves around 6 key points:
1) Where to build barriers for the best effect
2) When to build barriers
3) When to break barriers
4) The order of colours in the barrier
5) When not to 'knock off' your opponents counters
6) How to keep counters moving

The rules also allow for the length of the game to be altered. Each counter each person has equates to 30 minutes game play - meaning a game where each person has 4 counters lasts 2 hours, a 6 counter game will last 3 hours. It is not recommended to play with less than 4 counters each, due to the need to create barriers.

Money, adventure, & success in thirty minutes or less!

GettaLife is a fun card game illustrating the universal aspects of every day life. Players will draw and play cards to their individual Life Grid while simultaneously blocking their opponents from building theirs. As players build their Life Grid, they accumulate points, and after the deck runs out, the game ends and the player with the most points is crowned the winner and has GottaLife!

During play, however, players will also play Hard Knocks cards on their opponents' Life Grids in order to slow down their own progress, and will even play Damage cards on their opponents. Life Grids consist of four different tracks, or suits: Relationships, Wealth, Knowledge, and Experience. Each player must build the best Life Grid possible by balancing the development of all four suits with the hope of playing the Legend card and multiplying their points. Of course, the crowning achievement for any suit is for the player to achieve knighthood in one of their suits by playing all four cards in one suit without having any Hard Knocks.

item.description:
Plan, build, and develop a small town into a major metropolis. Use hex-shaped building tiles to add residential, commercial, civic, and industrial areas, as well as special points of interest that provide benefits and take advantage of the resources of nearby towns. Your goal is to have your borough thrive and end up with a greater population than any of your opponents.

Suburbia is a tile-laying game in which each player tries to build up an economic engine and infrastructure that will be initially self-sufficient, and eventually become both profitable and encourage population growth. As your town grows, you'll modify both your income and your reputation. As your income increases, you'll have more cash on hand to purchase better and more valuable buildings, such as an international airport or a high rise office building. As your reputation increases, you'll gain more and more population (and the winner at the end of the game is the player with the largest population).

During each game, players compete for several unique goals that offer an additional population boost – and the buildings available in each game vary, so you'll never play the same game twice!
